awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Impact of Hurricane Florence on well quality in communities surrounding coal ash impoundments in North Carolina
awd_abstract_narration:
A state of emergency was declared in North Carolina after Hurricane Florence caused storm surges, historic rainfall, and widespread flooding. The flooding caused collapses at coal ash storage sites. Coal ash is a waste byproduct from coal combustion and is one of the largest classes of industrial waste generated in the United States. Researchers have observed elevated levels of toxic metals, such as arsenic, hexavalent chromium, selenium, strontium, and vanadium, in the rivers and private wells impacted by coal ash. Little is known about the impacts of flooding on coal ash sites. There are more than 85,000 North Carolina well users in counties where coal ash impoundments have been impacted by Hurricane Florence, demonstrating a potentially significant risk of contamination. The hypothesis of this study is that private wells surrounding flood-impacted coal ash impoundments are at increased risk of heavy metal contamination. Through this RAPID grant, the research team will conduct temporal and spatial sampling to evaluate flood-associated well water hazards in communities potentially affected by contamination from coal ash impoundments. In addition, surveys will be distributed to obtain information to improve communication, education, and empowerment of impacted well owners. 

This research project aims to: 1) characterize well water heavy metal and bacterial contamination in counties with flood-impacted coal ash impoundments; 2) examine well users' risk perceptions, behaviors, and resource needs related to flood preparation and recovery; and 3) determine site-specific hazard proximities, hydrogeologic factors, well construction characteristics, and well user behaviors that increase the likelihood of contamination. Inorganic contaminants must be evaluated to ensure residents have safe, potable drinking water. Fingerprinting techniques have been developed to determine the sources of heavy metal contamination in drinking water, both from well water infrastructure and coal ash sources. However, these methods have not been widely utilized to systematically track the source of heavy metal contamination in flooded private wells. In addition, local North Carolina health departments are required to maintain well construction records, which can be used to further understand well construction factors that can influence contaminant transport during flooding. Finally, surveys of well owners will provide valuable knowledge about well owner preparedness and recovery behaviors. These information sources collectively support customized emergency planning resources and recovery strategies for communities near coal ash impoundments. This research project will provide insights into the potential sources and contamination pathways of microbial and toxic metal contamination in flood-impacted wells near coal ash sites and will help elucidate well owner resource needs that will enable autonomous well water protection.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research evaluated flood-associated well water hazards in communities surrounding coal ash impoundments and explore these communities? well recovery behaviors in North Carolina after Hurricanes Florence and Michael. In addition, with data collected in the aftermath of the 2016 flood in Louisiana, Hurricane Harvey (Texas), and Irma (Florida)., we provide a comprehensive multi-state characterization of flood-impacted microbial health risks of private wells, with emphasis on documenting the presence of opportunistic pathogens in private wells.

 

Identifying sources of hexavalent chromium

To determine the source of hexavalent chromium in well water, we (i) reviewed available methods to determine coal ash contamination in drinking water, (ii) validate the effectiveness of identified methods using wells previously identified as contaminated with coal ash, and (iii) used validated tracing methods to evaluate well water quality in five communities in NC surrounding coal ash storage facilities using a citizen science sampling campaign . A total of 39 publications involving the detection of coal ash contamination in water sources were reviewed, and we observed that there is not a specific method to use to determine if contamination is associated with coal ash sources. In addition, we found that hexavalent chromium is rarely considered in literature when evaluating coal ash contamination. When validating identified tracer methods, three methods emerged as the most sensitive methods for detection of coal ash contamination and all involved the use of boron and/or sulfate as indicators, rather than analysis of a large number of contaminants. We are currently exploring the application of these methods in our citizen science sampling.

 

Lead occurrence in North Carolina

To explore incidence of lead in well water in NC, we collected first draw and five-minute flushed samples from private wells in five counties. Lead in drinking water was greater in first draw samples, suggesting flushing systems reduces lead concentration as expected. In North Carolina, wellhead samples are typically collected after 5-15 minutes of flushing. During analysis, a 5 ppb detection limit is used. We observed that 95 wells had lead >15 ppb in the first draw (8.3% of samples), but also 2 wells continued to have high after flushing. Thus, collection of a flushed sample would miss notifying residents of high lead for 93 wells. In addition, 142 flushed samples (12.4% of samples) had lead levels between 1 and 5 ppb, which would be reported to residents as ?non-detectable lead? when using a detection limit of 5 ppb. Ultimately, we are exploring how sampling techniques that underestimate lead in water may impacts blood lead levels.

 

Multi-state evaluation of opportunistic pathogens (OPs)

We collected 79 samples from NC private well water after 5 minutes of continuous flushing at the most frequently used outlet in the home. As with the other hurricanes, samples were analyzed for Legionella spp., L. pneumophila, Mycobacteria spp., M. avium, and N. fowleri genes. Legionella spp. genes were the most commonly detected opportunistic pathogen genes, with 57% of samples were positive and 36.7% having quantifiable levels; however, L. pneumophila, the most commonly reported pathogenic species of Legionella, was detected in 20.3% of wells, with only 1 sampling having quantifiable levels. Mycobacteria spp. was detected slightly more infrequently than Legionella spp. in 46.8% of samples, and M. avium 12.7% with no quantifiable levels. N. fowleri was only detected in 2 samples (2.5%). Overall, the positivity rates and levels of opportunistic genes copies was similar to other states we have monitored, and suggest that OPs naturally with pathogenic species more infrequently occurring than genus-level markers. These results are being combined with the 139 samples were collected from private wells in Texas (n=61), Florida (n=40),and Louisiana (n=38) following flooding caused by Harvey in 2017, Irma in 2017, and flooding in 2016, respectively.

 

Environmental justice theory

Given the history of unethical studies on communities of color, (e.g., Tuskegee syphilis study), effective community engagement requires alternative, collaborative approaches to build trust, harness local knowledge, advance scientific understanding, and empower disadvantaged, marginalized communities commonly left out of the scientific enterprise. Recruiting for this study was improved by CEnR strategies, ensuring the collection of a diverse sample necessary for future assessment of potential disparities.  We worked with individuals from flooded neighborhoods as active participants in the research process, engaging them actively in the design process for recruiting, sampling, and reporting results. These bidirectional conversations between scientists and study participants supported the creation of equitable research designs and the co-creation of knowledge.
